title-group.article-title: Variation in Corrosion Resistance of Trivalent Chromate Coating Depending on Type of Zinc Plating Bath

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2007 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: Trivalent chromate coating is replacing the conventional hexavalent chromate coating applied on zinc plating. Zinc plating uses one of three types of plating baths (zincate, cyanide and chloride) according to the characteristics required of subject parts. It has been recognized that trivalent chromate coating provides different corrosion resistance depending on the type of zinc plating bath used. Zinc plating with chromate coating were analyzed to clarify the cause of the corrosion resistance variation with the type of zinc plating bath. It has been revealed that the chromate coating thickness and the condition of top SiOâ‚‚ layer vary with the type of zinc plating bath, resulting in corrosion resistance variation.

ref.mixed-citation: Shigeaki Miyauchi: "Anticorrosive Behavior of Silica in the Organic Coating on Galvanized Steel Sheet," Iron and Steel, Vol. 89, No. 1, p.116 -p.122 (2003)
Arata Suda: "Effects of Silica Addition on the Corrosion Resistance of Chromate Coating," Surface Engineering, Vol. 46, No. 5, p.437-p.441 (1995)
Hiroomi Noguchi et al.: "Chemical Conversion of Zinc Platings Using Trivalent Chromium (III) and the Resultant Corrosion Resistance," Surface Engineering, Vol. 51, No. 8, p. 856-p. 860 (2000)
